factoid: Natásha imagined what would happen at the ball in the brightly lit rooms with music, flowers, dances, the Emperor, and all the brilliant young people of Petersburg.
Natásha saw the prospect as splendid and could hardly believe it would come true, which seemed out of keeping with the chill darkness and closeness of the carriage.
Natásha understood what awaited her only after stepping over the red baize at the entrance and entering the hall.
Natásha removed her fur cloak after entering the hall.
Natásha, beside Sónya and in front of Natásha's mother, mounted the brightly illuminated stairs between the flowers.
Natásha remembered how she must behave at a ball only after mounting the stairs.
Natásha tried to assume the majestic air she considered indispensable for a girl on such an occasion.
Natásha felt her eyes growing misty.
Natásha saw nothing clearly.
Natásha's pulse beat a hundred per minute.
Natásha's blood throbbed at her heart.
Natásha could not assume the pose that would have made her ridiculous.
Natásha moved on almost fainting from excitement while trying to conceal it.
Natásha's attitude of trying to conceal her excitement became her best.
Other visitors were entering before and behind Natásha, talking in low tones and wearing ball dresses.
The mirrors on the landing reflected ladies in white, pale-blue, and pink dresses with diamonds and pearls on their bare necks and arms.
Natásha looked in the mirrors and could not distinguish her reflection from the others.
All reflections blended into one brilliant procession.
On entering the ballroom, the regular hum of voices, footsteps, and greetings deafened Natásha.
The light and glitter dazzled Natásha even more.
The host and hostess had been standing at the door for half an hour repeating the same words to various arrivals.
The host and hostess greeted the Rostóvs and Perónskaya with "Charmé de vous voir."
The host and hostess said "Delighted to see you."
The two girls in their white dresses, each with a rose in her black hair, both curtsied in the same way.
The hostess' eye involuntarily rested longer on Natásha.
The hostess looked at Natásha and gave Natásha a special smile in addition to her usual smile as hostess.
The hostess may have recalled the golden, irrecoverable days of her own girlhood and her first ball when looking at Natásha.
The host followed Natásha with his eyes and asked the count which of his daughters was her.
The host said "Charming!" and kissed the tips of his fingers.
In the ballroom, guests stood crowding at the entrance doors awaiting the Emperor.
The countess took a position in one of the front rows of that crowd.
Natásha heard and felt that several people were asking about her and looking at her.
Natásha realized that those noticing her liked her, which helped calm her.
Natásha thought that there are some like herself and some worse.
Perónskaya was pointing out to the countess the most important people at the ball.
Perónskaya indicated an old man with a profusion of silver-gray curly hair.
The old man was surrounded by ladies laughing at something he said.
Perónskaya said, "That is the Dutch ambassador, do you see? That gray-haired man."
Perónskaya indicated Hélène, the Queen of Petersburg, Countess Bezúkhova, who had just entered.
Perónskaya said, "How lovely! She is quite equal to Márya Antónovna."
Perónskaya observed that men, young and old, pay court to Hélène.
Perónskaya said that Prince (blank) is quite mad about Hélène.
Perónskaya said that those two, though not good-looking, are even more pursued.
Perónskaya pointed to a lady crossing the room followed by a very plain daughter.
Perónskaya said the lady was a splendid match, a millionaire.
Perónskaya said, "And look, here come her suitors."
